poem:
**Tears on the Trading Floor**

Rachel weeps silently, unseen  
Yet her tears ripple outward,  
Stirring the restless markets.  
Her sorrow remains her own,  
A private wave in a public sea,  
While far beyond her desk,  
The invisible PM shuffles papers,  
And we wonder who pulls the strings  
Of this vast, trembling economy.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Who’s really to blame for Labour’s troubles – Rachel Reeves or the invisible PM? | Gaby Hinsliff She is not the first chancellor to cry in public, and may not be the last. But Rachel Reeves is the first whose tears have moved markets. No sooner had the realisation dawned that she was silently weeping – over a personal sorrow she won’t be pushed into revealing, she insisted later, not a political one – as". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
